title: Ben Askren addresses future after loss to Demian Maia at UFC Singapore
text:
Ben Askren had another tough night in the UFC (Picture: Getty Images)

Ben Askren has ‘to think about things’ after his loss to Demian Maia at UFC Singapore, but made no mention of calling time on his career in the Octagon.

The former Bellator and One Championship champion was submitted by the Brazilian in the third round of their main event contest on Saturday in Singapore.

The tap out to a rear naked choke makes it consecutive losses within the distance for the wrestler after Jorge Masvidal dramatically ended his unbeaten record in just five seconds in July.

Where Funky goes from here is not clear, but he does not sound like he is ready to slide into retirement just yet, at 35-years-old.

‘I don’t know,’ said Askren on his future. ‘I need to go home and sit down and think about a lot of things. I’ve had a busy year, it was fantastic.

Demian Maia gets the tap! He executes the rear-naked choke to perfection. A master of his craft. 👊#UFCSingapore pic.twitter.com/iIP3znoA1L — UFC on BT Sport (@btsportufc) October 26, 2019

‘Even coming into this fight, I’m thinking who am I going to all out and I look at the division and everybody’s busy, the call-out tonight was going to be hard because there’s no one that makes a whole lot of sense right away

‘I’ll probably just sit and wait for a second and see what happens.’

Askren put his defeat down to ‘one bad decision’ and labelled Maia, who continues to win at 41-years-old, ‘the best grappler in the division, possibly in MMA ever.’

‘I think I won the first two rounds,’ continued Askren. ‘Who knows what they judges will say, they’re crazy, but I felt I won the first two.

‘We had obviously trained so much back in camp with a really good jiu-jitsu guy, but I guess I was over-confident there’s a reason he’s the best grappler in the division, possibly in MMA ever.

‘I was confident I was going to get the reversal, but I didn’t, I failed.

‘I just had one bad decision and at this level one bad decision is enough for a failed outcome.’

Askren echoed this sentiment on Twitter, writing: ‘Made a bad decision and I failed. Sorry to everyone who I let down.’

Made a bad decision and I failed. Sorry to everyone who I let down. — Ben Askren (@Benaskren) October 26, 2019

As for Maia, who turns 42 next month, he has two fights left on his UFC deal and is interested in scrapping with fellow veteran Diego Sanchez.
